channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Role of France Télécom Chief in Tapie Affair to Be Investigated
item.description: Prosecutors said Stéphane Richard would be formally investigated for his role in a case that has already swept up the head of the International Monetary Fund.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY

item.title: Turkish Leader Orders an End to Protests in 24 Hours
item.description: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan told his interior minister to bring nearly two weeks of demonstrations to a halt.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO, SEBNEM ARSU and CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: N.S.A. Leaker Vows to Fight Extradition From Hong Kong
item.description: In an interview with a local newspaper, Edward J. Snowden said he was not hiding from justice, and he accused the United States of hacking computers in Hong Kong and China.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Dozens of Shiites Reported Killed in Raid by Syria Rebels
item.description: Battalions of Sunni fighters stormed a village in eastern Syria, reportedly killing at least 30 people, in a reprisal raid that underscored the sectarian tone of the war.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HANIA MOURTADA and ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Study Finds Large Seabird Toll From Fishing Nets
item.description: Gillnets snare and drown at least 400,000 seabirds every year, and the actual figure could be considerably higher, scientists said.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL WINES

item.title: Cheetahs’ Secret Weapon: A Tight Turning Radius
item.description: A study shows that the large feline’s key to hunting success is not its speed but its skill at leaping sideways, changing directions abruptly and slowing down quickly.
item.dc:creator: By KATIE HILER
item.media:description: A cheetah at a game reserve in South Africa. New research suggests that the key to the predator's success lies more in its natural braking and maneuvering abilities than in its blazing top speeds.

item.title: French Air Controller Strike Disrupts Other Countries
item.description: The French civil aviation authority said that it expected 1,800 flights, roughly half of all scheduled, to be canceled Wednesday, but foresaw a return to normal by Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLA CLARK

item.title: Chinese Journalist Said to Be Detained in Beijing
item.description: The journalist, Du Bin, recently released a documentary about a women’s forced labor camp and has worked as a freelance photographer for The New York Times.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: The Risks of America Doing Too Much in Syria
item.description: Richard N. Haass, president of the Council on Foreign Relations, the American foreign policy think tank, sat down with Rendezvous’s editor Marcus Mabry to talk Syria. Mr. Haass gave a long laundry list of what issues are more important to the United States than the bloodbath in Syria, even as he detailed the risks of that widening conflict.
item.dc:creator: By MARCUS MABRY

item.title: Pope Is Quoted Referring to a Vatican ‘Gay Lobby’
item.description: Francis is said to have discussed a dossier he had received from his predecessor, Benedict XVI: “The ‘gay lobby’ is mentioned, and it is true, it is there.”
item.dc:creator: By RACHEL DONADIO
item.media:description: A gust of wind blows Pope Francis' mantle during a weekly audience in Saint Peter's Square at the Vatican on Wednesday.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: June 12
item.description: Sikhs commemorate the martyrdom of one of their gurus in New Delhi.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A girl waiting to receive a free drink in New Delhi during an event organized by Sikh devotees to commemorate the martyrdom of their fifth Guru, Guru Arjan Dev.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: China Celebrates First Dragon Boat Festival in Space
item.description: China’s Shenzhou 10 space capsule launched successfully Tuesday from the edges of the Gobi Desert, carrying three astronauts and some special holiday food.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: The Long March 2F rocket carrying China's manned Shenzhou 10 spacecraft blasting off from a launching pad at Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center in Gansu Province, China.

item.title: Syrian Rebel Attack Kills 60 Shiites, Activists Say
item.description: Syrian rebels have attacked a village in the country’s east, killing dozens of Shiites, mostly pro-government fighters, activists said Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Caution, Not Panic, Over Spread of Middle East Virus
item.description: The World Health Organization has called for health workers worldwide to be on the alert for cases of a deadly SARS-related virus that originated in the Middle East. Travelers to the region are being urged to take precautions.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: A man at a hospital in Dammam, Saudi Arabia, wearing a mask as a precaution against the new virus.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Protecting American High-End Research as China Rises
item.description: With a new book suggesting China is engaged in one of the biggest intellectual property heists of history, a prominent Chinese-American calls on Americans to remember that everyone is ‘innocent until proven guilty.’
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A girl riding a robot made by the Shanghai Jiaotong University at a science event in Shanghai.

item.title: Letter From China: Adopting Technology, but Not the Freedoms, of the West
item.description: The authors of a new book, "Chinese Industrial Espionage," say the Chinese government has prospered partly by transferring technology of the developed world to China since the 1950s.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: An Airport’s New Life, After Many Dramatic Landings
item.description: A Hong Kong airport long known for stomach-churning landings has been replaced by a cruise ship terminal.
item.dc:creator: By BETTINA WASSENER
item.media:description: Planes landing at the old Kai Tak airport used to have to swerve between Hong Kong's densely packed residential buildings.

item.title: Closing of State Broadcaster Leaves Greece in Turmoil
item.description: The decision to disband the Hellenic Broadcasting Corporation prompted protests in Athens and threatened the fragile coalition government.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.media:description: ERT employees continued to broadcast on Wednesday from the defunct organization’s offices in Athens and Salonika via digital television and the Internet.

item.title: South African Leader Cites ‘Progress’ in Mandela’s Condition
item.description: After four days in the hospital battling a lung infection, former President Nelson Mandela of South Africa “is responding better to treatment,” President Jacob Zuma said Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN
item.media:description: A mural of Nelson Mandela, the former South African president, in downtown Johannesburg.

item.title: Bridging Approaches to Mental Illness in Sierra Leone
item.description: By working with faith healers and witch doctors, a clinic in a war-ravaged district seeks to draw in mentally ill patients and address a medical problem usually framed in spiritual terms.

item.title: Al Fujayrah Journal: In the Crash of Bull Horns, Echoes of a Desert Land of Old
item.description: A competition called “bull butting” by some in the United Arab Emirates has entertained crowds and given bragging rights to bull owners for as long as people there can remember.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Two bulls in a traditional fighting match in Al Fujayrah, a city in the United Arab Emirates, last month.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: June 12
item.description: Violence in Taksim Square; surprise cut in Greece; Chinese labor camps; flights in France grounded by a strike; Damien Hirst explains his art; Nelson Mandela’s role in sports.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: A protester threw a firebomb at security forces, who used tear gas and water cannons to disperse demonstrators.

item.title: Behind Breakdown of Korea Talks, a History of Suspicions
item.description: North and South Korea have often squabbled over minor matters of protocol like the height of a flag or the rank of negotiators.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: French Foodies Fight Boil-in-a-Bag Trend
item.description: To the alarm of France’s gastronomes, a growing number of restaurants now offer pre-prepared meals. Now some want to change the law to limit the word “restaurant” to those that serve the real thing.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Eric Briffard, a top French chef, selecting ingredients at a Paris market.

item.title: India Ink: India Seeks Water Management Lessons From Israel
item.description: A delegation of Indian officials met with some of Israel’s leading experts to learn about technologies that keep the desert country green.
item.dc:creator: By DEBRA KAMIN
item.media:description: Women collecting water from a well on the outskirts of the town of Dudu, Rajasthan, on June 5, 2006.
